label: 263.  Robert Woodward Barnwell to Catherine Osborn Barnwell -- October 13, 1847
description: Robert Woodward Barnwell writes to mother, Catherine Osborn Barnwell, about life at South Carolina College, purchases made for his room and his decision to join the Euphradian Society. October 13, 1847.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Robert Woodward Barnwell writes to mother, Catherine Osborn Barnwell, about life at South Carolina College, purchases made for his room and his decision to join the Euphradian Society. October 13, 1847.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Columbia college, Oct 13th 1847. My Dear Mamma. It is now an half hour before study hours & I will devote that time to writing to you as I promised in Ted’s letter-- I have not received any letter since those brought by Wm Lowndes but expect one this evening-- My time is passing quite agreably & I hope profitably-- my quarters are not yet fixed as comfortably as I would like, from want of funds & also, on account of Joseph Mellichamp-- who did not want to put himself to any expense--. On this account I content myself with 1 basin stand & 1 basin between us-- which is rather inconvenient-- When I left home I expected to wait until December to furnish my room-- but as I fortunately got a vacant one, I was obliged to procure furniture at once-- I have bought-- a clothes press-- & a cot matress-- and paid for half of the following articles-- 4 chairs a basin stand, basin, glass & candles-- & dipper-- so that the expenditures of room come to. $13.50.-- I shall want a centre table-- I can get one for $2-- a tub for slop water-- & 2 candle sticks-- These Joseph Mellichamp & myself will buy to gether & square off when we part-- I will wait until[End Page 1] Wm Johnson comes to procure some more chairs a book case basin stand &c-- Dr Lieber has ordered us to buy a Butlers Ancient Atlas-- Tell Papa that McCarter & Allen have a branch up here as extensive as the one in Charleston, where books can be procured-- as well-- so that any text books I need I may get here-- As I mentioned, I have become a member of the Euphradian Society & for these reasons-- After a weeks acquaintance with the students here-- I was convinced by the cordiality of the Euphradians that I would pass a more agreable time as a member of that Society than if I joined the Clariosophics who seemed anxious for me to join-- only as it would be an increase to the number & seemed rather indifferent about it altogether-- & besides I had the opportunity of forming new acquaintances among the E_s without encountering the prejudices which I Knew existed against me in the Clariosophic in the persons of many of my old classmates, Several of the friends I have made here & all of the Euphradian-- & the majority of my class-- a comittee offered me the office of Secretary-- but I declined as it is rather troublesome & I preferred to[End Page 2] to be free to debate, which is the chief benefit to be derived--. Dr Henry called me up this evening on Greek, when he set us the lesson he made a long speech saying that as the period was short before the examinations came on-- we must get [has?] long lessons as possible-- of course I expected 500 lines & at any rate 250-- & lo & behold it was 50-- and of the 2d book too-- & 3 1/2 years ago I got 100--. So in Latin-- our longest lesson is 60 lines-- IN Mathematics-- 4 prop-- of the 4th book-- & history 8 pages once a week-- It is literally nothing so that I employ my time in reading I have taken Arnolds Rome out of the Library & am reading it carefully & mean for the present to employ myself in Reading, at the same time studying the lessons carefully-- A full grown man of 23. has just entered our class.-- & he has the reputation of being very smart-- so I will have to be “up & doing”-- but still with “a heart for every fate” Mr Preston came into Commons yesterday-- & took a seat next to me where he gave me an opportunity of seeing his insincerity-- as he commenced praising the coffee as being as good as he had ever drank, when positively it was so bad that he but sipped it & then put it down-- --[End Page 3] Joseph Mellichamp has just returned from the post office & announces that there is no letter for me-- so I must send this-- I would be glad if Papa would send me some money immediately, as I am upon my last dollar & this is to go to a subscription-- for Col Butlers family-- which the citizens of Richland have sent here & has been universally subscribed to-- Give much love to Aunt Mathews & all the children-- Tell Papa I belong to the Euphradian-- he will Know what I mean. & Give much love to him-- & accept-- no less yourself from Your affec Son R W Barnwell. Mrs. Wm H. Barnwell. Charleston. So. Carolina[End Page 4]
